keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and intended to 'shoot it up'.
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest, but police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle parked outside the airport.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm in commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
Cagle has a prior conviction for marijuana possession over 20 years ago and is considered a convicted felon under Georgia law.
Authorities were unaware he had already arrived at the airport, having been observed near the crowded TSA check-in area.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation, underscoring the seriousness and national significance of the event.
The incident occurred at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, the world’s busiest airport in 2024, with over 108 million passengers and a major role as headquarters for Delta Air Lines.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens emphasized that the individual’s mental health and possession of a firearm were key factors in the potential for tragedy.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised law enforcement for preventing harm, highlighting the broader national security implications.
This incident illustrates how early reporting by family members can prevent large-scale violence at high-traffic public locations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a convicted felon with a history of marijuana possession, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planned to 'shoot it up'. Though he was not armed at the time of arrest, police discovered an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle had already arrived at the airport and was observed near the heavily crowded TSA check-in area, which could have led to a mass casualty incident. Authorities, including the Atlanta Police Department and the FBI, responded quickly, with Cartersville police initiating the alert. The incident underscores the dangers of combining mental health challenges with firearm access, especially at one of the world’s busiest airports. The FBI and U.S. Homeland Security are involved, and officials like Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem have emphasized the tragedy averted through early reporting and swift action.
title: Man Arrested Inside Atlanta Airport After Making Threats to 'Shoot It Up'
